entry.title: A guide to Cambridge, the historic UK university city
entry.summary:
King‚Äôs College was founded in 1441 by King Henry VI as a 'finishing school' for scholars from Eton College. With its exquisite architecture, eclectic museums and cosy pubs, this charming university city is a welcoming place to while away a weekend during the colder months.
This article was produced by¬†National Geographic Traveller¬†(UK).
Compact Cambridge has an inordinately high concentration of beauty. Though only an hour north east of London, the fenland city seems to belong to another age entirely ‚Äî its gloriously unmodernised centre chock-a-block with soaring spires, historic colleges and cycling students trailing long scarves. Life centres around the university ‚Äî one of the world‚Äôs oldest and most prestigious, with more epoch-defining alumni than most people have had ho‚Ä¶

entry.title: Ireland‚Äôs Miche√°l Martin will visit China in the first trip by an Irish leader in 14 years
entry.summary: Ireland's Prime Minister Miche√°l Martin visits China starting Sunday, marking the first visit by an Irish leader in 14 years.

entry.title: Irish PM Martin to visit China as Beijing shores up EU ties
entry.summary: Irish Prime Minister Miche√°l Martin will visit China from Sunday, the Asian nation's foreign ministry said, the first such trip by an Irish Taoiseach since 2012 as Beijing shores up ties with individual members of the European Union bloc.

entry.title: Trump blocks chips deal, cites security, China-related concerns
entry.summary: President Donald Trump on Friday blocked U.S. photonics firm HieFo Corp's $3 million acquisition of assets in New Jersey-based aerospace and defense specialist Emcore, citing national security and China-related concerns.

entry.title: North Korea's Kim Jong Un visits greenhouse farm, encourages workers, KCNA says
entry.summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un inspected a greenhouse farm construction site along the country's border with China on Friday, and encouraged youths and troops working on the construction in the new year, state media KCNA said on Saturday.

entry.title: Italy's new car sales down 2.12% in 2025 as Chinese brands gain market share
entry.summary: Sales of new cars in Italy fell by 2.12% last year to 1.53 million units with Chinese brand BYD performing strongly, transport ministry data showed on Friday.

entry.title: Tesla loses EV crown to China's BYD as competition, tax credit expiry hit demand
entry.summary: Tesla ceded its crown as the world's top electric vehicle maker to China's BYD after annual sales fell for a second year, with intensifying competition, the expiration of U.S. tax credits and damage to the automaker's brand hurting demand.

entry.title: Sydney's food scene is booming‚Äîhere's what to try now
entry.summary:
Sydney Opera House‚Äôs distinctive roof is covered by more than one million tiles. The Australian city‚Äôs home-grown food scene is going from strength to strength, with in-water oyster experiences and garden bush-tucker tours on offer, plus a new-look Sydney Fish Market on the horizon.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Dawn breaks over Sydney‚Äôs seafood market and the clouds spill like fish scales across the vivid apricot sky. The flat-roofed, two-storey building beneath them ‚Äî the largest fish market in the Southern Hemisphere ‚Äî is already full of life despite the early hour, with workers busy unloading boxes of Balmain bugs (a species of lobster native to Australia). Seagulls squawk as they wheel in lazy circles overhead, while a pelican on the r‚Ä¶

entry.title: Is this really the world‚Äôs most dangerous bird?
entry.summary:
Towering at five and a half feet tall, sprinting up to 31 miles per hour, and leaping up to seven feet off the ground, cassowaries are the stuff of legends. They are the third largest bird in the world, weighing up to 175 pounds with sharp talons that grow up to five inches long. Their powerful kick, which¬†defends them from predators, can¬†break bones, damage internal organs, and even be lethal.¬†
‚ÄúThese birds look like an intimidating cross between a velociraptor, an emu, and a giant turkey,‚Äù says children‚Äôs book author¬†Beverley McWilliams, who wrote the book Cassowary Dad.
The two¬†recorded human deaths related to this creature have earned it the title of ‚Äúworld‚Äôs most dangerous bird‚Äù in the¬†Guinness Book of World Records.
But scientists say these striking birds are misunders‚Ä¶

entry.title: Coyotes mate for life‚Äîand grieve when their partner dies
entry.summary: A pair of coyotes (Canis latrans) in Griffith Park, Los Angeles. Unlike most other animals, coyotes have only one partner in their lifetimes. Scientists hope understanding coyote widowhood will someday help humans in their own grief. The loss of a longtime companion is a pain many people‚Äîand coyotes‚Äîknow all too well.¬† About a decade ago, scientists discovered that coyotes mate with just one partner in their lifetimes. But more recent research has turned to the sadder side of their lifelong love: the grief of widowhood. Scientists hope their inquiries can build compassion for these oft-misunderstood carnivores and perhaps guide the development of new mental health treatments for humans.¬† ‚ÄúWe have this opportunity to really understand what happens during loss a‚Ä¶

entry.title: To explore space, scientists want to turn the moon into a gas station
entry.summary:
This artist's concept shows the Lunar Flashlight spacecraft, a six-unit CubeSat designed to search for ice on the Moon's surface. Using near-infrared lasers, the Lunar Flashlight shines light into shaded polar regions on the Moon, while an onboard reflectometer measures surface reflection and composition. Using lunar ice to make rocket fuel could help future lunar settlements sustain themselves and provide a launch pad for astronauts to reach Mars.
One way or another, humans are returning to the moon. And this time, they‚Äôre staying‚Äîboth the United States and China plan to build their own lunar bases on the lunar south pole. That location isn‚Äôt random; it‚Äôs thought to contain reserves of precious water, either in the form of ice, buried water, or both. Those reserves could be used t‚Ä¶

entry.title: Inside the sting that took down Miami's '70s kingpins
entry.summary:
An investigation into Texas oil companies quickly became a sprawling hunt for 1970s drug-running in the Caribbean. Operation Lone Star, which tried to trace laundered drug and oil money, was one of the longest and costliest investigations in U.S. history.
This piece is excerpted from No Ordinary Bird: Drug Smuggling, a Plane Crash, and a Daughter's Quest for the Truth.
While my father was turning the [Bahamas‚Äô] Darby Islands into the center of a multimillion-dollar transnational drug smuggling empire, federal agencies were already laying the groundwork for his downfall.
Ironically, their investigation didn‚Äôt start with the drug business. It began in Texas, as a probe into oil price manipulation. A joint operation between U.S. Customs and the Internal Revenue Service, it‚Ä¶

entry.summary: A flood of questions drowned Jeanette in thought after she was diagnosed with cervical cancer. Would she be unable to conceive a child? Would she have to enter menopause at the early age of 31?

entry.title: Drop draft proposals on death penalty for Palestinians, UN rights chief urges Israel
entry.summary: The UN‚Äôs top human rights official on Friday called on Israeli authorities to abandon plans for new legislation that would impose mandatory death sentences exclusively on Palestinians, warning the proposals violate international law and fundamental human rights standards.

entry.title: Global equity funds see strong inflows in final week of 2025
entry.summary: Global equity funds saw strong inflows in the final week of 2025 as optimism over AI-driven market gains over the past year and a solid corporate earnings outlook lifted risk appetite.

entry.title: Hong Kong arrests 21 for corruption in building renovation crackdown
entry.summary: Hong Kong's anti-graft agency arrested 21 people on suspicion of corruption in relation to renovation work at two residential estates, it said on Friday.

entry.title: ASIA GOLD India, China flip to premiums on price retreat from record highs
entry.summary: Gold traded at a premium in top hubs India and China for the first time in about two months this week as a correction from all-time highs helped lift retail demand, which had been hit by an unprecedented rally in prices.

entry.title: German exporters face prolonged slump in key U.S., China markets
entry.summary: German exporters should prepare for continued weakness in 2026 in their two largest markets, the United States and China, with little prospect of recovery, the BGA trade association said on Friday.

entry.title: China taxes condoms, contraceptive drugs in bid to spur birth rate
entry.summary: They now incur value-added tax of 13%, the standard rate for most consumer goods.

entry.title: Asia's factories end 2025 on firmer footing as orders pick up
entry.summary: Activity swung back to growth in several key economies as export orders picked up, helped by new product launches.

entry.title: Stocks make upbeat start to 2026; precious metals extend sparkling rally
entry.summary: Stocks began 2026 on a positive note in holiday-thinned trade as investors braced for a year set to test the AI-led rally, usher in a change of guard at the Federal Reserve and potentially more market turbulence under Donald Trump's presidency.

entry.title: ÁÑ¶ÁÇπ‰∏™ËÇ°ÔºöNio„ÄÅKeppel Reit„ÄÅMandarin Oriental - The Business Times
China's Xi to host South Korea's Lee in New Year amid Japan tensions
entry.summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping will host South Korean President Lee Jae Myung on a state visit starting on Sunday, signalling Beijing's intent to strengthen ties with Seoul amidst strained relations with Japan over Taiwan.

entry.title: US stocks rose again in 2025 after overcoming turbulence from tariffs and Trump‚Äôs fight with the Fed
entry.summary: It was a scary good year for investors: Scary because the U.S. stock market plunged to several historic drops on worries about everything from tariffs to interest rates, but it was a great year for anyone with the stomach to stick through the swings.

entry.title: Taiwan vows to defend sovereignty after China's military drill
entry.summary: Taiwan President Lai Ching-te said on Thursday the island is determined to defend its sovereignty and boost defence in the face of China's rising ambition for expansion, after Beijing fired rockets towards the island in a military drill.

entry.title: Washington grants TSMC annual approval for US chipmaking tool shipments to China
entry.summary: The U.S. government has granted an annual license to Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing to import U.S. chip manufacturing equipment to its facilities in Nanjing, China, the chipmaker said on Thursday.

Earth is making its closest approach to the sun of the year
entry.summary:
The sun shines above the Earth‚Äôs horizon. Perihelion, the point when Earth is closest to the Sun, occurs annually in early January. Here's how the astronomical phenomenon influences our planet‚Äîfrom the length of our seasons to the way Earth moves through space.
At the start of the year, Earth will quietly reach a milestone in its orbit around the sun. Known as perihelion, this is the moment when our planet is closer to the sun than at any other point in the year.¬†
In 2026, Earth's perihelion occurs on January 3 at 12:15 p.m. EST or 17:15 UTC. This astronomical event occurs about two weeks after the December solstice. The exact timing shifts slightly from year to year because¬†the Gregorian calendar¬†doesn't perfectly line up with Earth's orbit. However,¬†leap years¬†account for so‚Ä¶

Millions battle seasonal affective disorder (SAD) each year, a type of depression typically occurring in autumn and winter. The condition affects 5 percent of Americans, and the same percentage globally. An additional two in five Americans battle with some form of the ‚Äúwinter blues.‚Äù

entry.title: January‚Äôs wolf moon is the last supermoon for nearly a year
entry.summary:
A super full moon rises behind the Empire State Building in New York City on January 31, 2018. It‚Äôs the first supermoon of the year‚Äîand after January, stargazers won‚Äôt see another for many months. Here's how to see it.
If you‚Äôve been hoping to spot a supermoon, mark your calendar. The full "wolf moon" on January 3 will appear bigger and brighter than usual‚Äîand it‚Äôs the last supermoon we‚Äôll see until November 2026.
A supermoon generally occurs when the moon‚Äôs full phase coincides with its close approach to Earth, known as its perigee. During these events, the orb can look up to 14 percent larger and 30 percent brighter than a micromoon, its farthest and faintest counterpart.

entry.title: Could AI ever destroy humanity? We may soon know.
entry.summary:
As computers and processors continue to get more powerful, many wonder when we will reach science-fiction levels of artificial intelligence. Tech companies are claiming machines more intelligent than us and capable of having their own agendas are just around the corner.
More than 50 years before ChatGPT could tell you what to cook for dinner, a 1968 science fiction film was shaping how we think about machines that talk to us.
In 2001: A Space Odyssey, a Jupiter-bound spacecraft is controlled by HAL, a computer that thinks for itself and has its own agenda. As the film progresses, HAL stops cooperating with the human astronauts it was programmed to assist and eventually turns off their life support.

entry.title: These 2025 discoveries reshaped what we know about the Bible
entry.summary:
The shrine that houses the traditional burial place of Jesus Christ at the Church of the Holy Sepulchre in Jerusalem. A team of archaeologists is conducting excavations under the structure's floor. From a garden at the Holy Sepulchre to new dates for the Dead Sea Scrolls, new research is offering detailed glimpses into biblical stories.
The biblical archaeology discoveries in 2025 paint a vivid picture of a rich, interconnected world whose traces echo down the millennia, in stone and text. entry.title: This decades-old drug could help you drink less alcohol
entry.summary:
Test tubes are used to measure the release rate of naltrexone at Go Medical Industries in Subiaco, Australia, in 2019. By blocking opioid receptors involved in pleasure and reward, the medication‚Äîavailable as a pill or injection‚Äîmay help some people drink less without quitting altogether. Naltrexone has long been used to treat alcohol use disorder. Now it‚Äôs gaining attention as a tool for people who want to cut back on drinking before it becomes a bigger health problem.
Kate Carbonari has been drinking since she was 15 years old. By her early 60s, she began to rethink her relationship with alcohol. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve gone through a lot of different drinking cycles in my life, and I feel like now, finally, as a society, we‚Äôre starting to say, ‚ÄòWhat are we doing with this alcohol here? entry.title: UN chief condemns Israeli amendments targeting UNRWA operations
entry.summary: The UN Secretary-General has condemned amendments adopted by Israel‚Äôs Knesset to a law aimed at ceasing the operations of the UN agency assisting Palestine refugees (UNRWA), saying the measures must be immediately repealed.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Health advances marked 2025 as wars and funding cuts strained systems
entry.summary: From eliminating deadly infections to expanding access to lifesaving vaccines, 2025 delivered meaningful progress for global health, according to the UN World Health Organization (WHO), offering cautious optimism at the close of a year marked by both breakthroughs and strain.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: WHO research shows COVID vaccines still crucial in preventing severe illness
entry.summary: Up-to-date vaccination remains the most effective way to prevent severe COVID-19 illness, new research from the World Health Organization (WHO) shows, even as the pandemic has officially ended.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Results expected 5 January after landmark elections in Central African Republic
entry.summary: Voting proceeded largely as planned in the Central African Republic‚Äôs first-ever combined presidential, legislative, regional and municipal elections, and ballot counting is now complete, the UN peacekeeping mission (MINUSCA) said on Wednesday, with results expected to be announced on 5 January.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Ukraine: Attacks disrupt heating as temperatures plunge
entry.summary: Recent attacks across Ukraine have killed civilians, damaged critical infrastructure and cut heating and power supplies for millions, UN humanitarians report, as temperatures drop below freezing.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Another child dies in extreme conditions in Gaza: UNICEF
entry.summary: A sixth child has died in Gaza this month as the enclave‚Äôs people continue to endure dire living conditions linked to freezing rains and the Israel-Hamas war, the UN Children‚Äôs Fund (UNICEF) has announced. The development comes as aid agencies urged Israeli authorities to reconsider revoking the licences of dozens of humanitarian partners that provide assistance across the devastated enclave from 1 January.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: China imposes curbs on beef imports to protect domestic industry
entry.summary: China will impose an added 55% tariff on beef imports that exceed quota levels from key supplier countries including Brazil, Australia and the U.S. in a move to protect a domestic cattle industry slowly emerging from oversupply.

author.name: Daphne Zhang, Ella Cao, Liz Lee

entry.title: In a breakneck digital era, the ancient art of Peking opera works hard to keep flourishing
entry.summary: The old and nuanced art of Peking opera is working hard to flourish in an era of digital entertainment and incessant screens.

author.name: China | Latest News from China Today | AP News

entry.title: Exclusive: Nvidia sounds out TSMC on new H200 chip order as China demand jumps
entry.summary: Nvidia is scrambling to meet strong demand for its H200 artificial intelligence chips from Chinese technology companies and has approached contract manufacturer Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co to ramp up production, sources said.

entry.title: China to impose additional tariffs of 55% on some beef imports from 2026
entry.summary: China will impose additional tariffs of 55% on beef imports from some countries including Brazil and the U.S. when shipment amounts exceed certain quotas, the commerce ministry announced on Wednesday.

entry.title: China factory activity picks up in December as orders rebound ahead of holidays
entry.summary: Surveys show that Chinese factory activity expanded for the first time in eight months in December, as orders picked up ahead of holidays and builders rushed to finish projects.

author.name: China | Latest News from China Today | AP News

entry.title: Silver shines in 2025 global market spotlight as softs, oil lag
entry.summary: Precious metals were the standout performers among commodities this year, with silver outperforming most major equity indexes and currencies, while gold hit record highs on economic and geopolitical risks.

entry.title: Asian stocks set for strongest annual jump in eight years on AI bets
entry.summary: Asian stocks drifted on the last trading day of a year that has seen investors brush off much of the tariff-related uncertainty and embrace AI chip stocks, while the dollar's dismal year has left the euro and sterling standing tall.

entry.title: Taiwan stays on high alert as Chinese ships pull back after massive drills
entry.summary: Taiwan stayed on high alert on Wednesday after China staged massive military drills around the island the previous day, keeping its emergency maritime response centre running, the head of the island's coast guard said.

entry.title: China urges Netherlands to correct Nexperia 'mistakes'
entry.summary: China urged the Netherlands on Wednesday to correct what it said were "mistakes" in relation to chipmaker Nexperia and remove obstacles to ensuring the stability of the global chip production and supply chain.

entry.title: Insight: A scammer's guide: How cybercriminals plot to rob a target in a week
entry.summary: A handbook found during a police raid on a compound used by a cyberfraud gang in the Philippines offers detailed instructions in Chinese for conducting scams and reveals a blueprint for grooming and deception.

author.name: Poppy McPherson, Han Huang, Ally J. Levine

entry.title: Philippines challenges Chinese vessel off northern province amid Taiwan tensions
entry.summary: The Philippines Coast Guard said it deployed an aircraft on Tuesday to challenge a Chinese research ship that serves as a base for submersible vessels after it was spotted about 19 nautical miles off the coast of northern Cagayan province.

entry.title: China's factory activity snaps record slump on festive stockpiling
entry.summary: China's factory activity unexpectedly grew in December, snapping a record eight straight months of decline, lifted by a rise in pre-holiday orders as officials seek to spur the $19 trillion economy's manufacturing sector without worsening deflation.

entry.title: UK calls for restraint over China's military drills around Taiwan
entry.summary: Britain said on Tuesday that China's military exercises around Taiwan increased the risk of escalation, and reiterated a call for restraint.

entry.title: Need-to-know travel changes coming in 2026
entry.summary:
Travelers who intend to fly in the new year can look forward to a number of updates at the airport, including the enforcement of REAL ID. From ID and entry and exit requirements to updated airline refund policies, these are the notable new rules affecting tourists.
Starting in 2026, travelers who fly will face a slew of updates from new security requirements at airports to new international routes, offering more options for booking once-in-a-lifetime vacations. Here‚Äôs everything to know about traveling by air this year.
After multiple delays since its introduction in 2007, the federal law requiring flyers to carry a REAL ID went into effect on May 7, 2025. Most newly issued ID cards are REAL ID-compliant, but travelers with older documents should check with their issuing sta‚Ä¶

entry.title: Germany's Merz tells Europe to assert itself to safeguard peace, prosperity
entry.summary: Europe must assert its interests more strongly to ensure peace and prosperity in 2026 amid challenges from Russian aggression, global protectionism and changing ties with the U.S., German Chancellor Friedrich Merz said in his annual address.

entry.title: Mexico to hike tariffs on China starting Thursday
entry.summary: Mexico's sweeping new tariffs on imports from mostly Asian countries are set to take effect on Thursday, in a move that will largely align Mexico with the U.S. as the neighboring countries place significant barriers on Chinese imports.

entry.title: Oil tankers still arriving in Venezuela despite US blockade, data shows
entry.summary: At least two oil tankers have made their way to Venezuela in recent days and others are navigating towards the country, a sign of state-run PDVSA's effort to expand floating storage and keep selling crude even as a U.S. blockade has reduced exports to a minimum.

entry.title: Poland urges Brussels to probe TikTok over AI-generated content
entry.summary: Poland has asked the European Commission to investigate TikTok after the social media platform hosted artificial intelligence-generated content including calls for Poland to withdraw from the EU, it said on Tuesday, adding that the content was almost certainly Russian disinformation.

entry.title: Air China to buy 60 Airbus planes worth $9.5 billion
entry.summary: China's flagship carrier Air China said on Tuesday that it and a subsidiary have signed an agreement with Airbus to purchase 60 A320NEO jets in a deal worth around $9.5 billion at list prices.

entry.title: China Aircraft Leasing to buy 30 Airbus A320neo aircraft
entry.summary: China Aircraft Leasing Group Holdings said on Tuesday its unit CALC (BVI) has agreed to buy 30 A320neo aircraft from Airbus .

entry.title: See the soul of Laos on this slow river cruise along the Mekong
entry.summary:
The Mekong‚Äôs earthy waters turn silver and gold around sunset, capturing a mystical essence in Laos. Slip into the slow pace of life in Laos, where a new Mekong cruise follows the river‚Äôs course past the pagoda-studded world heritage city of Luang Prabang, into a less-explored stretch of the waterway towards the capital Vientiane.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
The pan-roasted poop of the mulberry tree worm, it turns out, tastes like smoky green tea. This I learn sitting in the shade of a fiery-yellow flowering srisuk ‚Äòhappiness‚Äô tree, sipping the scat infused in hot water. ‚ÄúI discovered this when I saw one of my team collecting it,‚Äù says Veomanee (Veo) Douangdala. At first, her colleague was too shy to tell her what the droppings were ‚Ä¶

entry.title: How this 100-year-old sun compass unlocked polar exploration
entry.summary:
The inventor of this style of sun compass, Albert H. Bumstead, was a renowned tinkerer and the National Geographic Society's first chief cartographer. It took a National Geographic cartographer to invent a compass that worked where compasses don't.
The magnetized needle of a conventional compass wants to align with Earth‚Äôs magnetic field‚Äîhelpful, unless you‚Äôre near the poles, where the field tugs straight downward, rendering magnetic compasses useless. Pilot and National Geographic Explorer Richard E. Byrd, who hoped to fly over the North Pole in the summer of 1925, lamented this during a pre-trip address to the National Geographic Society, and his gripe sent chief cartographer Albert H. Bumstead tinkering. Bumstead developed a novel piece of hardware, a bit like a swiveling watch. Incline it to match one‚Äôs latitude and the single, 24-hour hand tracks the sun across the sky. Since the sun at northern latitudes sits due south at noon, an Arctic aviator can align the hand with the sun and set a compass dial by the timepiece. Simple. Elegant. Byrd took one to the Arctic in 1925 and again in ‚Äô26. He returned it to the cartographer engraved: ‚ÄúTo Albert H. Bumstead. For getting us there.‚Äù
See this object and more at the National Geographic Museum of Exploration starting summer 2026. Visit¬†moe.nationalgeographic.org. A version of this story appears in the January 2026 issue of National Geographic magazine.

entry.title: Why are cheetahs struggling to survive?
entry.summary:
In his new documentary special, Bertie Gregory follows cheetahs during the Great Migration in the Serengeti. Filmmaker Bertie Gregory's new documentary special captures the extreme challenges facing the world's fastest land animal.
In the world of wildlife adventure, Bertie Gregory has seemingly done it all. He‚Äôs tracked pumas in Patagonia, swum alongside great white sharks without a cage in South Africa, and camped through a frigid, six-day blizzard to observe emperor penguins in Antarctica. But up until now, he had never experienced Tanzania during the Great Migration‚Äîone of the last large-mammal migrations on Earth.
Over one million animals roam the Serengeti during this sprawling annual feat, but in his new documentary special, Cheetahs Up Close with Bertie Gregory (strea‚Ä¶

entry.title: 10 night sky events to see in January
entry.summary:
A photographer captures the aurora borealis during the peak of the Quadrantid meteor shower in Hemnes, Norway, in January. The month brings a strong lineup of celestial sights, including a supermoon, meteor activity, and several close moon-planet encounters.
January doesn‚Äôt skimp on cosmic sightseeing. The month begins with a vibrant supermoon, continues with the year‚Äôs best Jupiter view, and ends with multiple moon-planet conjunctions. Aurora activity continues to look promising this January, especially with long hours of winter darkness in light-chasing getaways like Alaska and Iceland.¬†
Here‚Äôs what to watch for in the night sky this month, with tips on snagging the best view.
As the new year begins, the night sky has its own midnight marker. Sirius, the brightest sta‚Ä¶

entry.title: What we're learning about the real strength of the female body
entry.summary:
A surfer prepares for one of the worst surfing mishaps, a wipeout that would hold her underwater, by running on the ocean floor while carrying a rock, Oahu Island, Hawaii. New science is upending long held assumptions that men are physically stronger than women. From fat cells that stretch like spandex to more flexible muscles, scientists are finding that women‚Äôs bodies are just as strong as men‚Äôs.
¬†On the slopes of Mount Kilimanjaro, the air thinned to a whisper, Deborah Clegg, a metabolic physiologist with a newfound appreciation for high places, found herself unfazed by the altitude. Her stride was steady, her energy unflagging. Clegg‚Äôs climbing partner, Biff Palmer‚Äîan accomplished nephrologist and mountaineer who had summited Everest and six of the world‚Äôs tallest peaks‚Äîfound t‚Ä¶

entry.title: How to plan your first visit to Serengeti National Park
entry.summary:
Three cheetahs stand on a large rock in Serengeti National Park, the most popular tourist destination in Tanzania. If you've never been on safari before, this Tanzanian park - home to big cats, elephants and antelopes galore - is a great place to start.
A¬†perfect morning on safari¬†could begin¬†with a sunrise balloon flight, drifting over a golden savannah. Down below,¬†zebras¬†call to each other with their distinctive, braying cries. After brunch on terra firma,¬†you can¬†scan for¬†lions¬†as your 4x4 vehicle threads its way through herds of¬†wildebeests, before arriving at a comfortable camp with tents shaded by acacia, kigelia or commiphora trees.
In Tanzania‚Äôs¬†Serengeti National Park, one of East Africa‚Äôs finest safari destinations, experiences like these aren‚Äôt just possible: they‚Äô‚Ä¶

entry.title: General Assembly approves $3.45 billion UN regular budget for 2026
entry.summary: The General Assembly has approved a $3.45 billion regular budget for the United Nations for 2026, following weeks of intensive negotiations and one of the Organization‚Äôs most important reform initiatives, UN80.

entry.title: Afghanistan to remain major crisis in 2026, UN, partners warn
entry.summary: Afghanistan is expected to remain one of the world‚Äôs largest humanitarian crises in 2026, UN agencies and humanitarian partners warned on Tuesday, launching a $1.7 billion appeal to assist nearly 18 million people in urgent need.

entry.title: Sexual violence against children ‚Äòentrenched, systemic and widespread‚Äô across DR Congo, UNICEF warns
entry.summary: Sexual violence against children has become entrenched, systemic and increasingly widespread across the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), with new data showing a sharp rise in cases since 2022, according to the UN Children‚Äôs Fund (UNICEF).

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Sudan: UN warns of unprecedented child hunger in Darfur as fighting fuels refugee exodus
entry.summary: Sudan‚Äôs deepening war is driving unprecedented levels of hunger, child malnutrition and displacement, UN agencies report, as new data from Darfur and a renewed refugee influx into Chad underscore the rapidly deteriorating situation.

entry.summary: Follow our live coverage as the General Assembly and its Fifth Committee meet today to finalize negotiations and vote on the United Nations‚Äô regular budget for 2026. entry.title: Prediction market for all the things is mostly sports, but they don‚Äôt talk about that
entry.summary: Kalshi is a prediction market that aims to let users bet on everything.‚Ä¶ Tags: betting, Financial Times, Kalshi, prediction, Sam Learner, sports

entry.title: Exclusive: China mandates 50% domestic equipment rule for chipmakers
entry.summary: China is requiring chipmakers to use at least 50% domestically made equipment for adding new capacity, three people familiar with the matter said, as Beijing pushes to build a self-sufficient semiconductor supply chain.

entry.title: Thailand-Cambodia ceasefire holds, but Bangkok says breaches delayed release of prisoners
entry.summary: A renewed ceasefire between Thailand and Cambodia over border clashes passed the 72-hour mark on Tuesday, an initial goal the countries set to secure a more lasting peace, but Bangkok said it had delayed the release of 18 Cambodian soldiers due to alleged breaches of the deal.

entry.title: Belarus shows off deployment of Russian nuclear-capable Oreshnik missiles on its territory
entry.summary: Belarus on Tuesday released video of what it said was the deployment on its territory of the Russian nuclear-capable hypersonic Oreshnik missile system, a development that bolsters Moscow's ability to deliver missiles across Europe.

entry.title: South Korea's President Lee to visit China from January 4 to 7 as Seoul seeks to restore ties
entry.summary: South Korean President Lee Jae Myung will make a state visit to China from January 4 to 7 and meet Chinese counterpart Xi Jinping, the Blue House said on Tuesday, aiming to keep up momentum to restore ties.

entry.title: The 2025 energy transition in eight charts: clean wins, dirty setbacks
entry.summary: For supporters of the energy transition, 2025 had plenty to complain about: the scrapping of U.S. clean energy policies, wind droughts in Europe, corporate retreats from wind power generation and a resurgence in coal-fired power output.

entry.summary: China‚Äôs top diplomat has slammed a record U.S. military sale to Taiwan. Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi on Tuesday also blasted what he called pro-independence forces in Taiwan and the leaders of Japan.

entry.title: In Ireland, women celebrate their own "Christmas" in January
entry.summary:
Nollaig na mBan‚Äîotherwise known as "Women‚Äôs Christmas," "Little Christmas," or "Little Women‚Äôs Christmas"‚Äîis a tradition that modern Ireland is reviving even as traditional gender roles shift. Nollaig na mBan is an old tradition from the country's south that modern women have turned into a day to celebrate their labor during the holidays.
Christmas isn‚Äôt everyone‚Äôs favorite holiday in Ireland. For Tracey Groome, a 48-year-old deputy principal who lives in Kildorrey in County Cork, the highlight of the season is Nollaig na mBan (pronounced "Null-ig na Mahn"), also known as Women‚Äôs Christmas, Little Christmas or Little Women‚Äôs Christmas. It‚Äôs ‚Äúthe night that I get to really relax because there‚Äôs no pressure on me,‚Äù says Groome. On Nollaig na mBan, gender roles reverse and it‚Äôs a day ‚Ä¶

entry.title: US approves Samsung chipmaking tool shipments to China for 2026, source says
entry.summary: The U.S. government has granted an annual licence to Samsung Electronics to bring in chip manufacturing equipment to its facilities in China for 2026, a person familiar with the matter said on Tuesday.

entry.title: Asian stocks pulled lower by tech, gold and silver cool off
entry.summary: Asian shares slipped on Tuesday, tracking Wall Street's tech slump, while silver and gold steadied after a sharp pullback from record highs took some froth off the precious metals' incredible rally.

entry.title: Dollar steady before Fed minutes, China's yuan breaches key level
entry.summary: The dollar held steady above recent lows on Tuesday ahead of the release of the minutes from the Federal Reserve's December meeting, while China's yuan strengthened through a key psychological level against the U.S. currency.

entry.title: Six China IPOs debut in Hong Kong after raising $900 million to cap banner year
entry.summary: Six Chinese companies made their Hong Kong trading debuts on Tuesday after raising about HK$6.99 billion ($900 million), with most opening above their IPO prices, rounding off a resurgent year for listings as the city dominated Asian equity capital markets.

entry.title: Exclusive: Soy trading firms to abandon Amazon protection pact in Brazil

entry.title: Two Chinese airlines plan Airbus jet purchases worth up to $8.2 billion
entry.summary: China's Spring Airlines and Juneyao Airlines on Monday announced plans to buy 30 and 25 Airbus A320-family jets respectively, according to stock exchange filings.

entry.title: Novo Nordisk cuts price of weight-loss drug Wegovy in China
entry.summary: Novo Nordisk is lowering prices of its top-selling obesity drug Wegovy in China, the Danish drugmaker said on Monday, as it braces for intense competition from local rivals next year when the patent for its blockbuster treatment ends.

entry.title: 20 travel adventures to book in 2026
entry.summary:
Dramatic cliffs, hidden coves and golden beaches line the Fishermen's trail in Portugal. The crackle of a campfire beneath a star-studded sky; the scent of cedar in old-growth forests; the thunder of a packed football stadium rolling through your chest ‚Äî this year‚Äôs most talked-about travel experiences engage all the senses. From stargazing in Northumberland to barefoot forest bathing in Japan and sport-fuelled escapes across South America, here‚Äôs our pick of 2026‚Äôs hottest trends.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
If travel in 2026 has a defining mood, it‚Äôs immersion ‚Äî the kind of adventures that stir something deeper within us, and that linger long after we leave a destination. And the data backs it up. UN Tourism‚Äôs latest outlook reports tha‚Ä¶

author.name: Duncan Craig, Oliver Smith, Shafik Meghji, Emily Brown

entry.title: Thai foreign minister hails ‚Äòvery productive‚Äô meeting with Cambodian and Chinese counterparts
entry.summary: Foreign ministers from Cambodia and Thailand convened with their Chinese counterpart on Monday as the Beijing government, building on its expanding presence in global diplomacy, sought to play a stronger mediating role in the violent border dispute between the two Southeast Asian countries.

author.name: China | Latest News from China Today | AP News

entry.title: AP Exclusive: China threatens detention in Xinjiang over banned Uyghur songs
entry.summary: Authorities in China‚Äôs Xinjiang region are threatening detention over the downloading, sharing or listening to a wide range of Uyghur-language songs, the AP has found.

author.name: China | Latest News from China Today | AP News

entry.title: What explains a mysterious rise in migraine attacks?
entry.summary:
A recent systematic review observed an upward trend in migraine severity in the United States. Climate change may be to blame. Weather patterns such as extreme heat and storm conditions have been linked to migraine attacks, and research shows those environmental conditions are becoming more common.
Cristian-Ovidiu Marin, 34, used to get mild migraine attacks every couple of months, usually when he was stressed out or didn‚Äôt get enough sleep. About four years ago, he began getting more¬†severe migraine flare-ups. ‚ÄúMy migraines have become more frequent and intense, often with sharp, pounding pain, nausea, and light sensitivity that wipes out my focus for several hours, sometimes the whole day,‚Äù says Marin, the CEO of an online game company based in Bucharest.
Scientific evidence‚Ä¶

entry.title: 'Java Man' returned to Indonesia
entry.summary:
Photo shows a skullcap fossil of a "Java Man" at the National Museum of Indonesia in Jakarta on Dec. 17, 2025. The fossil was recently repatriated to Indonesia from the Netherlands. The iconic Homo erectus fossil was welcomed home with a repatriation ceremony and a new museum exhibit in Jakarta.
Jakarta, IndonesiaMore than 130 years since its discovery in East Java, one of the most influential fossils in human history has finally returned home to Indonesia. The specimen, known as Java Man, transformed our understanding of own species and our ancient relatives. On December 17, through a repatriation agreement between the Netherlands and Indonesia, the fossil finished its long journey to the National Museum in Jakarta.
‚ÄúFor too long over a century, a significant part of our past‚Ä¶

entry.title: Gaza battered by heavy rains as humanitarian response continues
entry.summary: Severe weather conditions have led to further casualties and heightened health risks in Gaza over the past 24 hours, the UN aid coordination office (OCHA) reported on Monday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: SECURITY COUNCIL LIVE: Briefing on threats to international peace and security
entry.summary: The UN Security Council meets today to hear a briefing on threats to international peace and security following Israel‚Äôs recent recognition of the northern region of Somalia as an independent and sovereign state. Follow live below and UN News app users can click here and go here for all our in-depth meeting coverage.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN, US sign $2 billion humanitarian funding agreement for 17 crisis-hit countries
entry.summary: The United Nations and the United States on Monday formalized an agreement under which the US committed $2 billion in humanitarian assistance for global relief programmes, a move the UN‚Äôs top relief official hailed as a landmark commitment to saving lives amid escalating humanitarian needs worldwide.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN chief urges world leaders to ‚Äòget priorities straight‚Äô as New Year message calls for peace over war
entry.summary: As the world enters 2026 amid mounting crises, the UN Secretary-General Ant√≥nio Guterres has issued a stark but hopeful New Year appeal, urging global leaders to shift resources away from destruction and towards development, peace and people.

entry.title: China opposes recognition of Somaliland, affirms support for Somalia
entry.summary: China opposes any attempt to split territories in Somalia, the foreign ministry said on Monday, affirming Chinese support for the sovereignty, unity and territorial integrity of the East African country.

entry.title: China says it's 'seriously dissatisfied' with monument demolition in Panama
entry.summary: China is seriously dissatisfied with the demolition of a Chinese monument by the local government in Panama's Arraijan district in West Panama Province, a Chinese foreign ministry spokesperson said on Monday.

entry.title: Top diplomats of China, Cambodia and Thailand meet as Beijing seeks a stronger role in dispute
entry.summary: Foreign ministers from Cambodia and Thailand have convened with their Chinese counterpart to discuss the border dispute between the two Southeast Asian countries.

author.name: China | Latest News from China Today | AP News

entry.title: Thailand and Cambodia agree to consolidate ceasefire in China talks
entry.summary: Thailand and Cambodia plan to rebuild mutual trust and gradually consolidate a ceasefire after weeks of border clashes, Beijing said in a communique with the two countries following talks in southwestern China.

entry.title: Exclusive: VinFast-linked GSM plans Hong Kong IPO at up to $3 billion valuation, sources say
entry.summary: Vietnamese electric-vehicle taxi operator GSM, part of the Vingroup stable of companies, plans to list in Hong Kong in what could be the first IPO in the city by a firm from the Southeast Asian nation, two sources said.

entry.title: World shares are mostly lower in quiet holiday trading as China stages war drills near Taiwan
entry.summary: Shares in Europe and Asia are mostly lower in thin holiday trading as China stages military exercises near the island of Taiwan. U.S. futures were mixed.

author.name: China | Latest News from China Today | AP News

entry.title: China's Leapmotor targets annual sales of more than 4 million units in a decade
entry.summary: Chinese electric vehicle (EV) maker Leapmotor expects to sell more than 4 million vehicles a year within the next decade, CEO Zhu Jiangming said on Monday.

entry.title: China blames military drills for reef damage around disputed shoal
entry.summary: China said without naming any country that military activities such as bomb-dropping training in the waters around Scarborough Shoal have damaged the coral reefs there, state broadcaster CCTV said on Monday citing an ecological report.

entry.title: Stocks head for year-end record on Fed rate cut bets
entry.summary: Global stocks were on track on Monday to end 2025 at record highs, while the dollar hovered near its lowest in almost three months, reflecting expectations of further Federal Reserve interest rate cuts next year.

entry.title: China to issue digital yuan management action plan
entry.summary: China's central bank will issue an action plan on digital yuan management, with a new generation of digital measurement framework and mechanism effective from January 1, the Financial Times, a publication run by the People's Bank of China, said on Monday.

entry.title: China launches military drills around Taiwan amid tensions with Japan
entry.summary: China's military moved army, naval, air force and rocket force units around Taiwan for its "Just Mission 2025" drills, aimed at testing combat readiness and delivering a "stern warning" against moves toward Taiwanese independence.

entry.title: Inside Beijing's bid to tame the global iron ore market
entry.summary: China's state iron ore buyer is using increasingly hardball tactics against mining giants.

entry.title: Putin and Trump do not support European-Ukrainian temporary ceasefire idea, the Kremlin says
entry.summary: The Kremlin said on Sunday that Russian President Vladimir Putin and U.S. President Donald Trump do not support a European-Ukrainian push for a temporary ceasefire ahead of a settlement, and that Moscow thinks Kyiv needs to make a decision on Donbas.

entry.title: Technology is transforming travel and here's what's next
entry.summary:
Trolltunga in Norway has seen a surge in visitors in the past decade after featuring in social media posts. For better or worse, advancements in tech are transforming our trips. We look at the developments and how they might shape the future.
Thirty years ago, the world of travel was a far simpler place. There were no online travel agents; there was no seat-back inflight entertainment or in-car GPS. Mobile phones were brick-like, and could do little more than make calls ‚Äî using them for navigation was, at that point, unthinkable.
In the decades since, innovations in technology have completely transformed travel. Most recently, in September 2025, Apple introduced its latest AirPods, ushering in live translation capabilities to the earphones for the first time. Here‚Äôs how it‚Ä¶

entry.title: China welcomes Thailand-Cambodia truce ahead of trilateral talks
entry.summary: China on Sunday congratulated Cambodia on reaching a ceasefire with Thailand after weeks of deadly border fighting, as officials from the three countries prepared to open a two-day meeting in southwestern China.

entry.summary: Top diplomats from Thailand and Cambodia have started talks in China to address their border dispute.

entry.title: China's finance ministry says fiscal policies will be more 'proactive' in 2026
entry.summary: China's finance ministry on Sunday said fiscal policies will be more proactive next year, reiterating its focus on domestic demand, technological innovation and a social safety net.

entry.title: Russia opposes Taiwan independence in any form, FM Lavrov says
entry.summary: Russia opposes Taiwan‚Äôs independence in any form and considers the island an inseparable part of China, Russia's Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov said in remarks published on Sunday.
